newsitem.title: USA: Glickman says exports key to U.S. farm income.
newsitem.headline: Glickman says exports key to U.S. farm income.

text.p: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said Tuesday that the Clinton administration will continue to push aggressively to keep markets around the world open to U.S. farm products.
In a speech to agriculture industry lobbyists, Glickman said U.S. farm income is linked more than ever to agricultural exports because of recent changes in U.S. farm programs.
In that regard, U.S. farmers won an important victory last month when the House upheld President Clinton's decision to maintain normal trade relations with China, he said.
However, important negotiations with China still lie ahead regarding its bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).
"We need to make sure they come in playing by the same rules as everybody else in the club," Glickman said.
The United States will insist that China make important market access and other agricultural trade concessions before it enters the WTO, he said.

The Clinton administration is also committed to securing fast-track negotiating authority from Congress so it can expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to Chile and other countries in Latin America, Glickman said.
Otherwise, the United States risks losing out to the European Union and other competitors vying to increase their share of the growing Latin American market, he said.
Because changes in U.S. farm program have made producers more vunerable to market price swings, "our big challenge is to keep exports up," Glickman said.
Without the stabilizing influence of strong exports, "the peaks and valleys of commodity prices will put a lot of smaller and medium-size (producers) in great jeopardy," he said.
